The Alexander polynomial of the figure-eight knot, which has ten crossings and no zeros, is 1 + x^2 + x^4 + x^7. Therefore, the figure-eight knot cannot be untied by surgeries on any of itscomponents.

However, if we allow surgeries that change only the orientation of the component links (a process called "cable operation"), then we can obtain an unknot with a different number of crossings. For example, performing cable operations on the left-hand loop gives us an unknot with seven crossings, as shown below:

```
  A--B                  C--D

E   F---G              H---I
/ \ /|    <-------> / \ / |

/ \ / |             / \ / | 
P   Q QQUUUU--R     S   T T-V
/ \ / |            / \ / | 
W   X WXXXXXXX-Y    Z   U U-W
/ \ / |           / \ / | 

```
In this case, we have performed two cable operations to convert the right-hand loop into an unlink. We can also perform one more cable operation on either loop to get another unknot with seven crossings. In general, anyunknottedlinkcan bedeformedintoanunknotwithsevencrossingsbyperformingcablesonitsloops.Therefore,theunknowntingnumberofanyunknotteless than 4 is 7.

To determine this, we can use an algorithm called the "unknotting algorithm." This algorithm works by repeatedly finding and removing a pair of strands that are tied together in such a way that they cannot be untied without untying one of them. Here's how it would work with the given list of numbers:

    Start with two adjacent pairs of strands (2 & 4), (3 & 5), (5 & 6), (7 & 8)
 
     Remove strand 3 to create a loop between strands 5 and 7
 
     Now there are only three pairs of strands left: (1 & 2), (4 & 5), (6 & 8)
 
     Move down one position from index 1 to get to the next pair of strands
 
     Test if any two strands in the new pair (4 & 5) can be tied together so that they cannot be untied without first untying either one of them
 
     If no such tie exists, continue to the next pair of strands
 
     If such a tie does exist, return "unknot" because we have found a non-trivial knot

At each step, the algorithm will find a pair of strands that cannot be untied unless they are first tied together. After six steps, the algorithm will reach the last pair of strands (8 & 9). Since there is no way to tie these strands together except for the trivial knot, the unknotting algorithm has found a non-trivial knot and returned "unknot".

One such combination that works out to 0 moduloulo 11 is 4 + 6 = 10. So we know that at least one pair of consecutive elements in the sequence must be connected by a loop. In this case, there are many sets of connections that work, but one particularly simple set is {8, 10}, {10, 16}, {16, 22}, {22, 18}, {18, 20}. Substituting these into the above formula, we get:

1. Apply the move R2C (reverse Reidemeister move II) as many times as necessary to untie any crossings involving only one strand. 
2. Perform the move R3 (Reidemeister move III) on the obtained diagram until no more R3 moves can be applied. This will convert each crossing into a trivial knot or a single loop.

```

     ....
    .....

 .........
```

After applying R2C a few times, we end up with something like:

```

    ....p

  ......q

```

In this case, there's just one way to continue simplifying further using R2C moves. After performing R3 on this diagram, we're left with just one loop, which represents the unknot:

```

     ..sp
    ....px
   .....x
  ......q

```
